image.altText: The PwC logo is shown on an office building.

items.synopsis: PricewaterhouseCoopers began work on a top-level consulting contract with the federal government's regulator of tertiary colleges 24 hours before agreeing to acquire a $5.5 million stake in one such college, the controversial Top Education Group.

title.children: PwC worked for tertiary education regulator as it acquired stake in college

image.altText: Liberal Senator David Van apologises 'unreservedly' for interjecting against Jacqui Lambie

items.synopsis: Senator David Van confirms he took up an offer to move offices away from Senator Lidia Thorpe, after the senator made a complaint about him.

title.children: Liberal senator David Van confirms he moved offices after Lidia Thorpe made complaint

image.altText: A man in glasses and a suit stands between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags.

items.synopsis: A lease held by the Russian Federation for an embassy close to Parliament House will be cancelled by the federal government.

title.children: Russia to be blocked from building new embassy adjacent to Parliament House

image.altText: A man wearing a black cap fixes the collar of Trump's white jumper.

items.synopsis: Many of the familiar faces that surrounded Donald Trump in his final days in the White House have exited his orbit. But there is one man who remained dutifully by his side — and his loyalty may have made him a target of the FBI.

title.children: How the man who was constantly by Trump’s side ended up in court as his co-defendant

image.altText: Side by side photos of Anthony Albanese, looking up in a green tie, and Donald Trump, looking serious in a red tie

items.synopsis: Two years after Anthony Albanese openly criticised Donald Trump, the prime minister is now being urged to prepare for the very real possibility of his return to the White House, writes David Speers.

title.children: Is Albanese prepared for a possible Trump return to the White House?

image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith looks at the camera outside a court building

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: PM moves to shut down Russian embassy plans and Ben Roberts-Smith returns to Australia. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says the government will today introduce legislation to end Russia's lease for "a proposed diplomatic presence next to parliament house". "We anticipate this legislation will pass both the House of Representatives and the Senate this morning," he says. Home Affairs Minister Clare O'Neil says it comes after the government received advice on the proposed second Russian embassy in Canberra — which she says is an issue because it was set to be next to parliament house. "The Government has received clear national security advice that this would be a threat to our national security and that is why the government is acting decisively today to bring this longstanding matter to a close."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM says government will halt Russia's diplomatic lease in Canberra

props.alt: A man in a suit and glasses speaking at a podium in front of Austraian flags

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast)
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says the government will today introduce
legislation to end Russia's lease for "a proposed diplomatic presence next to parliament house"
"We anticipate this legislation will pass both the House of Representatives and the Senate this morning," he says.

Home Affairs Minister Clare O'Neil says it comes after the government received advice on the proposed second Russian embassy in Canberra — which she says is an issue because it was set to be next to parliament house.

"The Government has received clear national security advice that this would be a threat to our national security and that is why the government is acting decisively today to bring this longstanding matter to a close."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ten people remain in hospital four days after the bus crash in the New South Wales Hunter Valley that killed 10 other passengers. A NSW health spokesperson says: Eight people remain in a stable condition at Newcastle's John Hunter hospital Two others are in a stable condition at Sydney's Prince of Wales hospital Dozens were originally hospitalised after being injured in Sunday night's crash, but have since been treated and discharged. Meanwhile, members of the Hunter Valley's AFL community are rolling up their sleeves to replenish blood supplies used in the wake of the bus crash that claimed the lives of several players. Lifeblood says an urgent shipment of blood and plasma was also sent from Sydney to Newcastle in the wake of the crash.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 10 people still in hospital after Hunter Valley bus crash

children.content: Ten people remain in hospital four days after the
bus crash in the New South Wales Hunter Valley that killed 10 other passengers
A NSW health spokesperson says:
Eight people remain in a stable condition at Newcastle's John Hunter hospital
Two others are in a stable condition at Sydney's Prince of Wales hospital
Dozens were originally hospitalised
after being injured in Sunday night's crash, but have since been treated and discharged.
Meanwhile,
members of the Hunter Valley's AFL community are rolling up their sleeves
to replenish blood supplies used in the wake of the bus crash that claimed the lives of several players.
Lifeblood says an urgent shipment of blood and plasma was also sent from Sydney to Newcastle in the wake of the crash.

props.alt: A white man sitting in a chair giving blood

children.content: Matthew Norris from the Maitland Saints Australian Football Club has given blood this week.
(ABC News: Alexander Lewis)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Controversial Australian soldier Ben Roberts Smith has arrived back in Australia in the wake of a Federal Court ruling against him. The corporal unsuccessfully sued the Sydney Morning Herald, the Age and Canberra Times for defamation, with the court finding allegations of murder and bullying during his deployment to Afghanistan were substantially true. Speaking to Channel Nine in Perth, Roberts-Smith says his legal team will review the judgement. "I'm devastated with the result. It's a terrible outcome and it's the incorrect outcome," he says. "We will look at it and consider whether or not we need to file an appeal but there's not much more I can say about it. "We'll just have to work through it and I'll take the advice as it comes."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ben Roberts-Smith speaks after arriving back in Australia

props.alt: A white man with short hair wearing a suit

children.content: (AAP: Dan Himbrechts)
Controversial Australian soldier Ben Roberts Smith has arrived back in Australia in the wake of a Federal Court ruling against him.
The corporal unsuccessfully sued the Sydney Morning Herald, the Age and Canberra Times for defamation, with
the court finding allegations of murder and bullying during his deployment to Afghanistan were substantially true
Speaking to Channel Nine in Perth, Roberts-Smith says his legal team will review the judgement.
"I'm devastated with the result. It's a terrible outcome and it's the incorrect outcome," he says.
"We will look at it and consider whether or not we need to file an appeal but there's not much more I can say about it.
"We'll just have to work through it and I'll take the advice as it comes."

image.altText: Young male migrants standing on a boat waiting for rescue.

items.synopsis: At least 79 migrants drown, with hundreds more said to be missing after their overloaded boat capsized and sank off Greece, in one of Europe's deadliest shipwrecks in several years.

image.altText: An orange sun sets over a city skyline, casting orange light across the horizon

items.synopsis: New Zealand's economy has entered a recession, after the latest data confirmed the country has recorded two consecutive quarters of negative growth, while local investors await the release of the latest employment figures. Follow live.

title.children: New Zealand in recession as its economy shrinks, US pauses interest rate rises, ASX to open higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New Zealand's economy is in recession, after the March quarter National Accounts figures from Stats NZ confirmed a second consecutive quarter of the economy shrinking. A commonly accepted technical definition of recession is two consecutive quarters of declining gross domestic product (GDP), which is the key measure of a country's economic activity. Stats NZ reported a 0.1% fall in GDP over the first three months of this year, backing up a downwardly revised 0.7% slump in economic activity during the final three months of last year. New Zealand's economy still grew 2.9% over the past year, due to strong growth in the June and September quarters, but a rapid string of interest rate rises has taken all the momentum away over more recent months. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand's (RBNZ) cash rate currently sits at 5.5% and it was amongst the first central banks to start raising rates to combat inflation. The RBNZ started raising rates from a record low of 0.25% in October 2021, more than half a year before the Reserve Bank of Australia started raising rates here in May 2022.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New Zealand officially falls into recession

children.content: New Zealand's economy is in recession, after the
March quarter National Accounts figures from Stats NZ
confirmed a second consecutive quarter of the economy shrinking.
A commonly accepted technical definition of recession is two consecutive quarters of declining gross domestic product (GDP), which is the key measure of a country's economic activity.
Stats NZ reported a 0.1% fall in GDP
over the first three months of this year, backing up a downwardly revised 0.7% slump in economic activity during the final three months of last year.
New Zealand's economy still grew 2.9% over the past year
, due to strong growth in the June and September quarters, but a rapid string of interest rate rises has taken all the momentum away over more recent months.
The
Reserve Bank of New Zealand's (RBNZ) cash rate currently sits at 5.5%
and it was amongst the first central banks to start raising rates to combat inflation.
The
RBNZ started raising rates from a record low of 0.25% in October 2021
, more than half a year before the Reserve Bank of Australia started raising rates here in May 2022.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's according to NAB's chief economist Alan Oster, who says the data the bank is collecting is pointing towards the Australian economy starting to slow right down, suggesting the RBA's rate rises are starting to have an impact. "We're seeing it in our business survey, we're seeing it in our internal data, we're seeing essentially new orders in retail and wholesale at levels we haven't seen for any period other than when the economy sort of got into deep trouble," he told RN Breakfast. "We have lowered our growth expectations, essentially to 0.5% over the course of the year. We've already had 0.2 of that. "So we're basically saying no growth in the rest of the year, unemployment goes up a little bit, but it's exactly what the Reserve Bank is trying to do. "It's trying to essentially take money out of households, and get them to spend less, and therefore hopefully get inflation down a bit quicker." So is Australia heading for a recession? He says it depends how you define it. "It depends on what your definition is. Two quarters of negative growth? I don't buy that. But I do buy the idea that if our employment goes up by 1% over a year, that's a bit of an issue, and our forecasts have that. "So I think it's 50-50, it's going to look and feel recessionary to a lot of people is the bottom line."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian economy going through 'a really big slowdown' that will 'feel recessionary'

children.content: That's according to NAB's chief economist
Alan Oster
, who says the data the bank is collecting is pointing towards the
Australian economy starting to slow right down,
suggesting the
RBA's rate rises are starting to have an impact

"We're seeing it in our business survey, we're seeing it in our internal data, we're seeing essentially new orders in retail and wholesale at levels we haven't seen for any period other than when the economy sort of got into deep trouble," he told RN Breakfast.
"We have
lowered our growth expectations
, essentially to 0.5% over the course of the year. We've already had 0.2 of that.
"So we're basically saying no growth in the rest of the year, unemployment goes up a little bit, but
it's exactly what the Reserve Bank is trying to do.
"It's trying to essentially take money out of households, and get them to spend less, and therefore hopefully get inflation down a bit quicker."
So is Australia heading for a recession? He says it depends how you define it.

"It depends on what your definition is. Two quarters of negative growth? I don't buy that. But I do buy the idea that if our employment goes up by 1% over a year, that's a bit of an issue, and our forecasts have that.
"So I think it's 50-50, it's
going to look and feel recessionary
to a lot of people is the bottom line."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NAB's chief economist Alan Oster was speaking to Hamish Macdonald on RN Breakfast a short time ago about the US Federal Reserve leaving interest rates on hold overnight. He said the rate pause was expected, but was taken by surprise when the members of the Fed considered the future of rate rises in the current cycle. "What wasn't expected was essentially that they have what's called the dots in other words, all the members of the Fed vote for where they think rates are gonna go," he said. "And the average said two more rate rises. That was a surprise."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fed's rate pause wasn't a surprise, but 'two more rate rises' was

children.content: NAB's chief economist
Alan Oster
was speaking to Hamish Macdonald on
RN Breakfast
a short time ago about the US Federal Reserve leaving interest rates on hold overnight.
He said the rate pause was expected, but was taken by surprise when the members of the Fed considered the future of rate rises in the current cycle.
"What wasn't expected was essentially that they have what's called the dots in other words, all the members of the Fed vote for where they think rates are gonna go," he said.
"And the average said two more rate rises. That was a surprise."
